results.title: A Working couple
results.creator_credit: Oliver Howes, Gil Brealey and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human Face of Japan”.
Most Japanese live in the big cities, many of them are salaried company workers, living in housing estates and traveling long distances to work. For many people, life is a struggle. This focuses of Mr Yokohama, a professional office employee and his wife who runs a chemist. Their lives provide an insight as to what its like to live in Tokyo, with a population of twelve million.

results.title: Tomorrow and yesterday
results.creator_credit: Oliver Howes, Gil Brealey and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human Face of Japan”
The Japanese are well known for their ancient civilisation with its tradition and brilliant festivals as well as its high technology and future-oriented attitudes. This film shows how the two meet.

results.title: The Rice ladle
results.creator_credit: Oliver Howes, Gil Brealey and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human Face of Japan”.
Japanese women these days face difficulties, especially in the professions as society emphasises the traditional role as the home-maker. Looks at a widow working as a cook’s assistant and a girl studying to be a pop star.

results.title: Mind, body and spirit
results.creator_credit: Bob Kingsbury, Suzanne Baker and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human Face of China”.
The medical services for China’s rural people - 80% of the population - were built upon the integration of Chinese traditional and western medical practices. Most basic health care needs can be met by the barefoot doctors. In Chienchou People’s Commune we seethe role played by two of these doctors. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels. Narrated by John Bell. “With thanks to the Central Newsreel and Documentary Film Studio of the People’s Republic of China.”

results.title: Something for everyone
results.creator_credit: Suzanne Baker, Bob Kingsbury and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human Face of China”.
The production team is the basic unit of a People’s Commune in China. Following Chian Li-he and his family at home and at work, the film explains how a commune operates. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Son of the ocean
results.creator_credit: Bob Kingsbury, Suzanne Parker and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human Face of China”.
One of the grandest links in China’s network of waterways is the Yangtze River. The river was closed to foreigners in 1949. In this riverboat journey we travel through the Yangtze Gorges on the way from Chungking to Wuhan and the story of the boat crew and passengers unfolds. Narrated by John Bell. Contains Chinese language with English subtitles. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bob Kingsbury, Suzanne Parker and Film Australia

results.title: It is always so in the world
results.creator_credit: Bob Kingsbury, Suzanne Baker and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human Face of China”.
Shanghai in 1979, with its 11 million people, and the second biggest city in the world, was for years dominated by foreign powers. Following the end of the revolution in the early 1970s, China is now caught up in the urgency to accelerate progress and this is expressed by a massive campaign to make everyone personally committed to the aim of the 4 modernisations: to catch up with the west in science, education, agriculture and defence by the year 2000.
results.title_for_label: It is always so in the world
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bob Kingsbury, Suzanne Baker and Film Australia

results.title: One hundred entertainments
results.creator_credit: Bob Kingsbury, Suzanne Baker and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human Face of China”.
Based in Sian, on the old Silk Road to the west, the Shensi Provincial Acrobatic Troupe is skilled at their art, and loved by the people who see them perform. The Troupe’s tradition goes back two thousand years. It spends as much as eight months of the year on tour.
